Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You want a ride into town?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: You bet.

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Got me an audition tonight.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Well, you just remember, if you can't kick front, kick back, 'cause at least you're kicking... Ten minutes, okay?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: I've just been waiting for the right spot to sing in... I'm so nervous...

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: I'm good, though. There ain't but one Sueleen Gay -- I don't mean to be conceited, but really it's true. I've been taking special coaching lessons from Zeke Willard -- he's just wonderful. Teaches you how to phrase; that's really important. And breathing. Well, you know all about that. Anyway, I wrote this song.

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Oh, listen, I really do go on. Here's your check. Sure has been nice talking to you.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Sorry. He sees a tape recorder and gets upset.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: He's my father.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Haven Hamilton is your father? Can you arrange an interview?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who the hell is playing piano? Get that hippie out of here... He's got a tin ear. I asked for Pig, dammit. I'm moving on 'cause I gotta get to the airport. When you get my backups straight, then we'll talk about cutting this tune here.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir. I'm here putting together a film. I would like to ask some questions.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Foreigner?

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: I'm from BBC television.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where the hell is that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Linnea.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: How you doing, Haven?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: oh, fine. Couldn't be better.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You ladies got room for a spare?

Speaker: stew
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Joan?

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Glad to see you. Ester'll be glad, too.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: I'1l get your bag.

Speaker: glenn
Dialogue: Am I late?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Late!  Oh, Jesus!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Delbert, how are you?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I'm fine. This here is John Triplette. Triplette, like you to meet the Honorary Mayor, Haven Hamilton.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Good to meet you.  Bud, have them move the horses.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Pleasure

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Where is she?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Still inside the plane posing for pictures and signing autographs. She's got a new album cut again. She'll be down in a minute. But she'll be late for the Opera if she doesn't hurry. Bud, get the plane on the walkie-talkie.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: They don't seem to be answering. The ambulance boys are here, though. Barnett always expects them to get there like a shot. That thing only goes a hundred fall bore with the sirens going.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Thank you, Bud.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Bud, tell them to move the horses. Promised this strip would be spic and span.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Listen, we'll go get the car and come back. This'l1 be going on for a while.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You bet. She's probably talking to somebody about their sick child. You know how she is.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Hi, Norman.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Sure is nice to see you all again. I never thought I'd see you again after the last time.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh, Norman, you worry too much.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Norman, how are you?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Fine. Just fine.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Sure have missed you all, though. Oh, where's Tom?  Isn't he with you?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Don't worry about old Tom.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Have you thought about your future and what America needs to examine...

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: How long was she out?

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Not too long. But she keeps passing out.

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: Just give your manna that vitamin E. Makes a world of difference.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Here she is again.

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: Okay, let's get her to the wagon.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Eater's been asking for you.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: She's been in the hospital two weeks yesterday.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: It's hard to say. Doctors thought she'd come home a week ago. All it was was appendix.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Did an exploratory and according to them, she needed an overhaul.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: green
Dialogue: I see... Well, those doctors are real miracle workers.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Maybe you can look after me a little.

Speaker: pearl
Dialogue: We had these two city boys come in last week. One or them said his Ford truck had cut off his foot. The other one said that wasn't true. Then the first said he looked just like Eddie Black when he said that...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Bud, would you be sure to get the oil changed?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Ya... where do you want me to take it?

Speaker: pearl
Dialogue: Do you remember Eddie Black? He had those blue eyes.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where you always take it. There's nothing special about this time.

Speaker: pearl
Dialogue: And they started pounding on each other. But the one without the foot was strongest.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Bud, you're going to have to show up at the hospital tar me I gotta get back to that session.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Okay. Anything you want me to say?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Say I had to get back to the session. ~ God -- All school did for you, you can put in a thimble.

Speaker: pearl
Dialogue: The cops came through and broke it up. I finally just had to call Chet and say, 'Chet, get over here. There are two old bays here breaking up the furniture...'

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Is that what you're going to sing?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: No -- That's exercises. My coach says you have to do exercise because the vocal chords are muscle and need to be stretched. Every time you stretch them, the middle part sets stronger. That's the place where I sing.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You think I got any kind of a voice?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: You sure do it loud.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Is that good?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: It's not bad.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You think I should take lessons?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: If you're serious. Being serious is real important.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You serious?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Wade -- I've been working toward this audition for years.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Well, honey, I sure hope it comes your way then.

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: You think it will?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Sure thing.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You did, huh?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Too long.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: All his life.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Me, too.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You having any fun?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's the most important thing -- to have -- fun

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Long enough to have fun.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: What do you think of him?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Hal? Well, Hal and I have been friends for a long time.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: You go to school together?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: No, we never did that

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Oh --

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: We're connected by a relative. One time, one of his aunts married one of my uncles. That was a long time ago, though. How'd you come to work for him?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Well, I really think he's got a chance.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: You do?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Oh yea -- There has never been a better time for something new.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: He ain't really new.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: He is to a lot of people.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: He was a good Judge, but that was a long time ago.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: You know, I'll bet you he makes it with a majority.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Where are you from?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Southern California.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: You always live there?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Spent time in Arizona. Why?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Well, I admire your optimism, and I just wondered if it was regional. You ever see any movie stars?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: I know a couple.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: No kidding -- Wait till I tell Linnea. Who?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Ah... Peter Finch.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Peter Finch -- he's English.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I never heard of him. Name somebody else.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Ryan O'Neal.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: You really do?  ~ God -- How come you know them?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Oh, you meet them at parties and stuff.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I'll be damned. Boy, if you could get Ryan to say something about Hal Phillip Walker, wouldn't that be something?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Well -- maybe. Let's see what happens here.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I'll be dammed.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Have your children been deaf since birth?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Yes -- yes, they have. It was a real shock at first, especially since my daddy's a preacher, but Delbert and I have been blessed by their being here.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: When did you start singing?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: When I was little, in church.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Isn't it unusual for you to be working with a black choir?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Yes, it is --

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Well, can you tell me why?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: It just is.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: How long have you been with them?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: About three years.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: And before?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Just my church and my boys. We all had to go to school and learn hand talking. I just thank the Lord they can see.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Do you ever do any writing?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: No, I don't.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Are you a close friend of Haven's?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: No, mostly his wife's. She's in Paris, France, right now. My husband Delbert is real friendly with him. Delbert's in law. Does work for him.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Do you like him?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: He's a member of our congregation.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: You got the money?

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Right here.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Well, don't lose it. Last time I gave you twenty-five dollars, you lost it.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Well, that just happened that time.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Well, it better not happen again.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: You lost twenty-five dollars once before that, too, near Christmas time -- I remember that real well now. December 9th, to be exact.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: You got a real good memory, Star.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: I remember when I just saw you. Skinny Winnifred. Jesus, you were skinny.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: What do you have to buy?

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Feed, mostly. Thought we'd get something for the kids.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Okay by me - I'd sure like to see that Opryland.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Grand Old Opera --

Speaker: star
Dialogue: I hate that music.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: I know that, Star.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Oh, my God!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Norman, just sit there and don't puke.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Hey, mind if I walk with ya?

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: You a musician?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Do you have people in Nashville?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No -- Just coming to Nashville, that's all.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I don't care. I pay you people twenty-five bucks an hour and keep you working steady. Now either go on or turn around. But move.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't worry, Norman. There's no blood. Nobody's hurt.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Hurt my foot...

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Have you seen a woman about so high?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: She had on high heels?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Need a ride?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Barbara, I'd like to talk to you and Barnett alone.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Anything you say.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Doctor says you'll have to go on out now

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Excuse me, Barnett, how's she doing?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I feel as if I know you. I'm John Triplette... a friend of Del Reese... I was at the airport. I just wanted to introduce myself. I'm a great fan of hers. If there's anything you need, just give me a call. I'm at the Sheraton South.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: She's going to rest now.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Okay, I just wanted to see if I could help out at all.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I appreciate your concern, but she has to rest, so you can go on home.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Oh, sure.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: What do you really want?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Not a thing, Barnett, really. I need a little information. But, ah, it can wait.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: You bet.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Okay. Thanks.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Well, it's exhaustion, pure and simple, and you're going to have to take a rest or you're going to be in big trouble.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: She has to be at the opera tomorrow night and then she can go home.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: She's not going anywhere, Barnett. This is precisely what I'm talking about. She is collapsing. She cannot go on without a rest or she will have to stop altogether for a long time.

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: Well, I have to go:  It's too late to be replaced, and, besides, I just can't do that. Those people get disappointed. They've come in from all over, you know, and this Miss Foxy who's been writing to me for years is going to be there from Michigan.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: You cannot leave this bed until I say so. The two of you have to understand that. Barnett, you've got to stop this dovetailing and give her some rest. You don't need to make that much more money.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: It's not the money. The friends and neighbors love her and they want to see her. We got a debt to the public.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Well, they are not going to see her tomorrow night, and I suggest you get on the phone and make the necessary arrangements.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We just got a gold record.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Do they have a show to give it to you?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No  Hell, some secretary in New York just hands it to you. Only this one kept dropping it out of the box.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Did it break?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Dent it a little. Boy -- just she couldn1t even find it. She had a hamburger on her desk that looked three weeks old.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: How long have you been together?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Probably a little too long.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Do you study at all?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Depends on what I'm studying.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: When do you need her?

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: Monday night.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: You want her to sing, too?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: I can do benefits

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: Twenty dollars for her and ten for you.

Speaker: managzr
Dialogue: Well, do you want a blonde?

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: How does she look?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: You know... blonde.

Speaker: delbert
Dialogue: Okay, I'll get you your money.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I can only give you fifty a week here and ten bucks for the benefit.

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Money's no object.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: You go here Monday night and be there at eight sharp and look flashy you know what I mean?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Are you sure you know what you're doing?

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Hundreds of times.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Well, there's a couple of girls in Printers Alley if you got any questions. I know I've seen that G- string stuff for sale someplace around.

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Don't you worry about Sueleen Gay.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: That's for sure. At the airport - that's where it was. At the airport, there in one of those gift shops... Anyway, you better take a break.

Speaker: sueleen
Dialogue: Thanks. You are just a wonderful person.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Linnea?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Yes. Who's this?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm here.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Who is this?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Tom. You remember?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: I'm not sure. Where?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Remember, about a month ago, your church choir cut a record?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, I met you that afternoon in the control room and we...

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Oh, Tom, of course. What are you doing in Nashville?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'd really like to see you.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Or course. You should come over to the house. The boys would love to meet you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's not quite what I had in mind.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Well...How have you been?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, they removed my heart last week, but I'm doing fine except my nose fell off. Looks a little funny.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Look, I find you attractive and I want to see you, so I'll call you when I get to my place.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Hey, what are you doing?

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Just fixing this strap here

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I know what you're doing. I've done it too long not to know. But if you're going to hunt down food, get enough so you won't have to do it again right away. Peanut butter's good. Man can last a long time on peanut butter.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Tommy Brown, you are the whitest nigger I have ever seen.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Let's go --

Speaker: tommy
Dialogue: I don't think Norman's done yet.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: We've heard enough. Come on.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Hell, you're whiter than that old boy up there.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Where the hell are you going, Oreo cookie?

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Hey, there - You seen my Winifred?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: You got a place to stay?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No. Probably stay at a motel tonight.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: You in music?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Get in.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: You should have stayed. Ester's been wanting to see you.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Come on back to bed.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yeah, you bet. You're really terrific. You know what I mean?

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Just a minute.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hiya. Listen, is Linnea there?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Listen, 1'm sorry I didn't call a little sooner. I sorta got tied up. Listen...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Who is this?  It's Tom.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What do you mean?  You said you wanted to see me.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What the hell is going on?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I would like to talk to...

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Yes, air.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Can I help you?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Yes, sir. I need a room

Speaker: green
Dialogue: I think we can do that. Come in.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Green's the name.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Kenneth Fraser. Glad to meet you...

Speaker: green
Dialogue: My wire's been in the hospital so things might be a little dusty, but the sheets are clean and the bath's down the hall.  You're in music, I guess, aren't you?  'Cause my niece sings most of the day. That won't bother you, will it?

Speaker: green
Dialogue: I didn't think it would. She's calling herself L.A. Joan this- week. Last week it was Dakota. Guess if you have to change your name a state's as good as anything.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: She sure sings nice.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: My wife and I think so, but we're family. Your family's always good or bad depending on how you look at your family. What do you do, pick or sing?

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Oh... a little of both. Just thought I'd look around at Nashville for a while.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: When you run out or money, 'cause you will here, you can go sing at Bishop's Pub. They let you pass the hat. All these kids do that. Most every place doesn't want to bother with you.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: I'm not really a musician.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Well, don't be shy. I got the address here. Anytime you need it. Room's twenty-five dollar! a week and you can have breakfast with me if you like.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Suits me.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Listen, do you know anything about cars?

Speaker: green
Dialogue: A little. What do you need?

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Get ready. We're going to the hospital.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: we're going.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: You'll have to stand closer to the mike.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: You've only got time for one more take, unless you've got another twenty-five dollar!.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Oh, don't you worry. You sure done your best. It'll be fine. I just know it.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Okay, you're on.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Hi... This here is Albuquerque speaking. You don't know me yet but ya will after I sing you this song that I've wrote called...

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Okay, come in the booth. You'll have to wait for the disc.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: HI. Look at those flowers. Did you grow those.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Ester and me did;  My niece picked then. She's just here from California.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: That's good,  I've never seen anything so healthy.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: You sit there for a moment and let me see if she's sleeping.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Excuse me. Are you in music?

Speaker: glenn
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Well, neither am I. But my niece is.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Wake up. You'll sleep the day away.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I called Connie and she said not to worry, She'll fill in for you.

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Sorry I'm late.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You're not.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Where's Bill?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Sleeping.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Out.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: He got killed at a turkey shoot.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Your brother?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Yes. I was in my Sophomore year at Harvard.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Harvard?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Business School so I can run Haven's business.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: What is a turkey shoot.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: You go out in the woods and shoot targets -- Whoever shoots the most wins a live turkey

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: How in the world did he get shot?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Some guy was drunk and hit him. Accident. Haven almost killed him.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Sorry to bother you, Bud.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Yes, sir. Like you to meet Opal.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Need to have you check these out before he goes on that Walker benefit.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Sure thing. Put them here... I'll take them.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Thanks... I'll... go say hello to your mom.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: She's in Paris.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Oh... Well... Have you heard from Barnett?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Let me know when you do, all right?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: You bet.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I'll just be in here.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Do you know Barbara Jean?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Sure do. Good friend of Haven's.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Haven's not going to talk to me.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Sure he will.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: I'm Opal.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Oh yes, I'm John Triplette.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: I'm gathering information about the characteristics of music people. I just finished a documentary on Gandi.

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: The architect  His buildings are drippy. You know, like sand and castles. Then I got this assignment. They want to start in two weeks.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: opal
Dialogue: What? Oh. A film.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Where'd you get the cake?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Someone gave it... Here, you want this... I'll...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: A little worried. Fine, though.

Speaker: announcer's voice
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen, Haven Hamilton.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: We want to send special wishes to Barbara Jean who is in the Baptist Hospital. She collapsed yesterday morning at the plane christening. Send your prayers and letters to Baptist Hospital, Nashville, Tennessee. Barnett said she wept because she couldn't be here with you friends and neighbors. But your faith in the great Almighty will bring her back here just to be what you want her to be... Dialogue: Listen, we're suppose to sing on TV day after tomorrow. At the park...

Dialogue: National?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Yes. Percy Warner Park'.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Where are you staying?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Is that for that Walker guy?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Yes, but we're just singing.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Sue was trying to get hold of you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Come on. He's a crook.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What crook?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I'm a Roman Catholic. You're Baptist, I bet. Catholic means universal, everything, know what I mean?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I'm a scholar of the Bible as well and we're all going to answer to God. Have you read the book of Revelations?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You ever read the 'Apocalypse Unsealed?'

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm not coming anywhere near that place. He's a rotten guy.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's not true.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: He's a politician.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: He saw us at Tammany Hall.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: The Hell he did. Look, I'll see you in the morning.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You bet. Nine, right?  But count me out of that other thing.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: My mother. died in '72. They told me after. They said they couldn't find me before, so they told us after.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: They said go see the chaplain.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: I'm sorry but I have to go.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I'm a hundred years old and when I'm two hundred, I'll die.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Well, for heaven's sake. You're just about everywhere, aren't you?

Speaker: thiplette
Dialogue: I came out to see how you all were doing.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I think I should tell you I know why you're here. The answer is no ... we don't get involved in politics.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Well, that's not entirely true, Barnett. At least not according to Haven.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Haven? Hell,' we've been playing poker together since we were fourteen.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: I guess that's why he thought you right want to help out.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: He knows better.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Well, it's probably because it would help him.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: How is that?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Everybody likes to be as good as their word.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Whose word?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: His Word.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: His word? Are you telling me Haven promised you something?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: That's pretty close. He's going to be on the bill. Why not put Barbara Jean on with him?

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: Barnett..

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Get her feet up.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Okay, honey.

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: Oh, Barnett, I'm so sorry.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Honey, it's okay... How do you feel now?

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: All those people...

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'll take care or it

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: You're so good.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: She's fine now, folks. Just too soon after the hospital, I guess.  She won't be able to continue and she's in the bus crying her eyes out, because she doesn't want to disappoint the people who love her the most.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Come on, come on. You don't want to waste your energy on that fool.

Speaker: glenn
Dialogue: She's frail. You never saw anybody so frail. I've seen her breathe hard just standing still, dammit. You're selfish. Worst selfish I've ever heard. What if she died?  Would you like that?  You'd probably say she faked it so they could make money. Well, you're just dumb.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: We could invite them to the park.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: They can come to the concert in the park.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I said 'no!'

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: You can see her tomorrow at Percy Warner Park...

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Triplette, I want to talk to you.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I got trapped and you know it, so let's have some rules.

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Absolutely. Listen, Barnett, I understand your position.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: No, you don't, so don't say you do. Bunch of damn liars. What do you get out or this?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Nothing; Barnett. It's my job.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Your job, huh.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: She will not appear on the stage or support that Walker guy and you can't have any of his signs up while she sings. She'll be on first and out of the park before he shows up. There will be no pictures, no questions, no answers or tying her name up with his now or in the future to come. Any money she makes will go to the President of the United States.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: We'll see you tomorrow. I'll send her three songs over this afternoon. She'll be done about ten minutes after she starts and Walker better not show up till she's through. Now, get out of here.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Barnett?

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Well, Barnett, I have this terrific song I've been working on. It would be a natural for Barbara Jean. Like you to take a look at it.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I'm very busy right now.  Get me Haven.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: It'll just take a minute. Here, I'll even hold it for you.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: I don't know where you got this, but something tells me you stole it and I hate thieves.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Aren't you an engineer...?  I know you -- Don't you work at one of those cut a record places...? Twenty-five bucks a shot, isn't it? Usually their last twenty-five...

Speaker: mc
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Berguan. And now we bring you, 'Albuquerque.'

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Hello, everybody. My name is Albuquerque.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: I'm going to sing a wonderful tune.

Speaker: mc
Dialogue: We'd 1ike~to announce the winner of tonight's contest. Albuquerque, How about some applause for a darling little lady

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Oh, I'm not through.

Speaker: mc
Dialogue: That's all, folks.

Speaker: mc
Dialogue: Here is the twenty dollars first prize money and a seat in the grandstands and now let's turn the show over to Al Allen in the race stand.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Congratulations to Albuquerque and welcome, everyone, to the Memorial Race for Billy Apple, who died a week ago in a wreck at this very track, and we want you to know his last words were, 'Are the other fellows all right?'

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Want you all to save a dime every day and next Saturday we'll take up a collection and give it all to Billy Apple's wife. Share. Their four kids will sure miss their daddy. Want to announce Bob Trilltree is out of the hospital now. Hope you'll be back with us soon. All right, would you stand, please?

Speaker: al
Dialogue: This is for Billy Apple. Okay, ladies and gentlemen, let's pick ourselves a winner.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Winifred.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: Hi! Star.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Winifred, the kids want you home and so do I.

Speaker: albuquerque
Dialogue: I won first prize.

Speaker: star
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You're really terrific, you know what I mean --LINNEA rolls over and faces him.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: I have to go.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Wrong.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: I have to go. He sighs.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Stay.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Car pool?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: When did you think it would happen?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: I'm not sure.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I knew when I first met you.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How old are you?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Older.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Thirty?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'm twenty-eight

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Older than thirty?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Terrific!  Who was that black guy? A friend of yours?

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: That's unkind.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Come on, you ever been attracted to a black guy?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Just a minute.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'll talk to you tomorrow.

Speaker: linnea
Dialogue: That's what you said before.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I know. Goodbye.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Maybe you better keep that.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Sure... you're a fine boy, Ken, you really are.

Speaker: kenny
Dialogue: Okay... you get to sleep. I'll see you in the morning. Good night.

Speaker: green
Dialogue: Good night,

Speaker: green
Dialogue: I guess she's not coming...

Speaker: glenn
Dialogue: Listen, could you give her this for me?

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: Sure thing.

Speaker: glenn
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: They screwed up. You go on after the choir.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen, Miss Barbara Jean...

Speaker: barbara jean
Dialogue: I want to thank you for all your good wishes. You are so important to Barnett and me. Now I want to sing a special song for all our soldier boys.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Barnett!  My God, Barnett  I'm shot!

Speaker: triplette
Dialogue: She's... oh, my God... there's blood here...  Ladies and gentlemen, I don't know what to say.

Speaker: barnett
Dialogue: Have your friend Triplette take you to the hospital.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What'd she do, faint again?  I'm getting tired of waiting in the car.
